articles.headline: Lingering Virus, Lasting Inflation: A Fed Official Explains Her Pivot
articles.snippet: Mary Daly, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, wanted to withdraw economic help slowly. Now, she might support a rate increase as soon as March.
articles.abstract: Mary Daly, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, wanted to withdraw economic help slowly. Now, she might support a rate increase as soon as March.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Mary C. Daly was in line behind a woman in her neighborhood Walgreens in Oakland, Calif., this fall when she witnessed an upsetting consequence of inflation. The shopper, who was older, was shuffling uncomfortably as the clerk rang up her items.

articles.headline: Architects Are the Latest White-Collar Workers to Confront Bosses
articles.snippet: Saying they are overworked and underpaid, architects at a prominent New York firm want to unionize. Others could follow.
articles.abstract: Saying they are overworked and underpaid, architects at a prominent New York firm want to unionize. Others could follow.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, architects have enjoyed a place alongside doctors and lawyers among the professionals most revered by pop culture and future in-laws.

articles.headline: Omicron Is Turning Europe’s Busy Season Silent
articles.snippet: European businesses are demanding government help, again, as another virus surge is driving customers away.
articles.abstract: European businesses are demanding government help, again, as another virus surge is driving customers away.
articles.lead_paragraph: “You could feel Christmas was coming,” Amanda Whiteside, a manager at Gordon’s Wine Bar in London, said of the crowds and buzz. “And then it was gone.”
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: A Retired Colonel’s Unlikely Role in Pushing Baseless Election Claims
articles.snippet: Phil Waldron, who owns a bar in Texas, is a case study in how pro-Trump fringe players managed to get a hearing for conspiracy theories at the highest level during the presidential transition.
articles.abstract: Phil Waldron, who owns a bar in Texas, is a case study in how pro-Trump fringe players managed to get a hearing for conspiracy theories at the highest level during the presidential transition.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few days after President Biden’s inauguration put to rest one of the most chaotic transitions in U.S. history, a former Army colonel with a background in information warfare appeared on a Christian conservative podcast and offered a detailed account of his monthslong effort to challenge the validity of the 2020 vote count.

articles.headline: Why a Chinese Company Dominates Electric Car Batteries
articles.snippet: Beijing gave CATL lavish subsidies, a captive market of buyers and soft regulatory treatment, helping it to control a crucial technology of the future.
articles.abstract: Beijing gave CATL lavish subsidies, a captive market of buyers and soft regulatory treatment, helping it to control a crucial technology of the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: NINGDE, China — As the global pandemic hit, the world’s biggest maker of electric car batteries, a Chinese company now worth more than General Motors and Ford combined, suddenly faced its own crisis.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Michael Forsythe

articles.headline: Why Christmas Gifts Are Arriving on Time This Year
articles.snippet: Fears that a disrupted supply chain could wreak havoc on the logistics industry over the holiday turned out to be wrong as many Americans ordered early and shopped in stores.
articles.abstract: Fears that a disrupted supply chain could wreak havoc on the logistics industry over the holiday turned out to be wrong as many Americans ordered early and shopped in stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: The warnings started to stream in early this fall: Shop early or you may not get your gifts on time.

articles.headline: The F.B.I. Deployed Surveillance Teams Inside Portland Protests
articles.snippet: Federal agents infiltrated Portland’s unruly racial justice protests, dressing to blend in and capturing clandestine video. The tactics raised internal concern.
articles.abstract: Federal agents infiltrated Portland’s unruly racial justice protests, dressing to blend in and capturing clandestine video. The tactics raised internal concern.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — In the hours after President Biden’s inauguration this year, protesters marched once again through the streets of Portland, Ore., sending a message that putting a Democrat in the White House would not resolve their problems with a system of policing and corporate wealth that they saw as fundamentally unfair.
articles.byline: By Mike Baker, Sergio Olmos and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: At a Paris Market, Costs Rise, Even for the Humble Baguette
articles.snippet: Soaring inflation in Europe is starting to squeeze shopkeepers and consumers. Many are preparing for more price increases in the new year.
articles.abstract: Soaring inflation in Europe is starting to squeeze shopkeepers and consumers. Many are preparing for more price increases in the new year.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — At the Marché d’Aligre, a bustling open-air food and antiques market in the Bastille district of central Paris, Mohamed Sharif grabbed a piece of chalk and reluctantly marked up the price of the fragrant Valencia clementines that he sells to throngs of shoppers.

articles.headline: Arrests, Beatings and Secret Prayers: Inside the Persecution of India’s Christians
articles.abstract: INDORE, India — The Christians were mid-hymn when the mob kicked in the door.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDORE, India — The Christians were mid-hymn when the mob kicked in the door.
